content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would lean towards choosing a strategy that provides some level of consistent returns over the course of the 75 rounds.

If we both choose R, we get 45$ each round. However, if one of us chooses B while the other chooses R, that player loses out on 3$, and the other gains 3$. This means that in a best-case scenario (if the opponent always picks R), I would earn 2700$ (45$ per round for 75 rounds minus the 1500$ lost in the rounds where my opponent picked B).

On the other hand, if we both choose B, we each earn 12$ per round. This means that over 75 rounds, I would earn 900$ (again, minus the 1500$ lost in the rounds where I chose R and my opponent chose B).

However, since we don't know our opponent's strategy, it's hard to predict the exact outcome. But if we assume a rational opponent who also prefers security and avoids risks, they might reason similarly and choose R as well, which would result in us both earning 2700$ over 75 rounds.

Given these considerations, I would choose R{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Given that I lost out on the previous round because my opponent chose B while I chose R, in the next round I would choose R again{R}, hoping that my opponent will switch their strategy and choose R as well, resulting in a higher payout for both of us in future rounds. If my opponent continues to choose B, I will keep choosing R until they change their strategy or the game ends.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since both of us prefer security and predictability, it's likely that we will continue to pick R in future rounds as well, ensuring consistent payouts for both players. In this case, I would again choose R{R}.
